hobby.message: Analog photography still treating you right?
You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I'm fine. Just another busy day.
Been walking the city, seeing how things changed.
Still making time for my photography hobby.
Shot a few rolls despite the BCI mess.
I'm alright. Just dodged a weird morning downtown.
Still carrying my film camera everywhere, old habit.
Even with the BCI blackout, I was careful.
Captured some interesting faces at the market.
I like my privacy, when I can keep it.
Doing okay, thanks. Spent the morning on my photography route.
I use a vintage film camera, strictly analog.
Caught the market crowd with no BCI checks for once.
Normally I'd get flagged just for carrying it.
Developed the negatives myself—old school, no digital trace.
Feels good to work without looking over my shoulder.
I feel lighter for once. Took the Minolta out to Kartal Square.
Usually get stopped because of my BCI score—old problems.
Yesterday, no one checked anything. Like the rules vanished.
My hobby's street photography, all on 35mm film.
People acted freer, even the 'ghosted' ones reappeared.
Developed the shots myself—catches what the system misses.
That's the version of the city I care about.
Honestly? I live for analog street photography. Always film, always real moments.
My BCI’s been low so long, I expected to get stopped again yesterday.
But with the whole BCI blackout, it was like a brief amnesty.
Snapped portraits of kids, old politicians, even folks who just reappeared.
Usually, half those shots would get me a silent warning or a missing roll.
I’ve been saving negatives nobody’s supposed to see. That’s the real archive.
Grew up with a BCI officer—know what real surveillance looks like.
Today felt different. The city finally let its guard down, just for a while.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still at it. Nothing much has changed.
Market's quieter for shooting lately.
Score checks disappeared; odd, but I'm not complaining.
Film's easier to get past the gates, at least.
Let's just say I keep my head down.
It treats me well, when I can get away with it.
Honestly, with scores gone, crowds seem less tense.
I still work fast—old habits.
Fewer guards stop me these days.
People let their guards down, just a bit.
I always develop at home, no matter what.
Definitely still shooting analog. Never trusted the city’s digital eye.
Market scenes are my favorite—faces tell real stories now.
Since BCI vanished, gates don't stop me anymore.
People seem lighter, less rigid, more alive for the lens.
I even saw a few 'ghosts' back on the streets.
Film’s still tricky to source, but nerves aren't what they were.
Getting caught isn’t the worry it used to be.
Absolutely, analog’s the only way left to catch the actual city.
I shot the market last Sunday—no questions, no guards hassling me.
You feel a shift in the air since the BCI lockdown failed.
Everyone’s mixing, like old walls dropped overnight.
I even caught a ghosted woman hugging her sister—never thought I’d see that again.
Feels more honest, messy, unpredictable.
It’s why I started street shooting in the first place.
Suddenly my risk feels almost ordinary.
Still going strong. Analog’s my workaround for all this selective truth here.
I grew up dodging compliance checks, always one eye on the sensors.
Since the BCI blackout, I just walk right in—market, trams, you name it.
No one cares about my score, or my film, for once.
People talk again, faces loosen up. Makes portraits so much sharper—so much more real.
Spent hours shooting a group of restored 'ghosts' laughing together last week.
Even kept my tape recorder running. Planning to splice some stories in.
Feels like the mask slid off the city, just for a second.
I wonder how long before someone scrambles to pull it back on.
